message: This is about tax cuts for hardworking men and women.
Much-needed tax relief is on the way.

It is an honor and a privilege to continue representing Missourians in the 115th Congress. I look forward to working with the incoming administration to roll back burdensome and unnecessary regulations, improve access to quality, affordable health care, and keep the promises we’ve made to our nation’s heroes.

During my stop at the Boys & Girls Club of Southwest Missouri, I talked about the Excellence in Mental Health Act and how our state’s participation in a new demonstration program will help Missourians get the care they need.

The Obama administration handed down a record-breaking 600 major new regulations, imposing more than $700 billion in costs on our economy. All of that excessive red tape places a huge burden on the farmers and small businesses that create jobs in Missouri and across the nation. The REINS Act, which I’m once again proud to cosponsor, paves the way for stronger economic growth by giving Congress the ability to put a stop to any massive new regulation that will hurt families and job creators.   http://www.blunt.senate.gov/public/index.cfm/2017/1/blunt-backs-bill-to-curb-excessive-regulations

Today, I spoke on the Senate floor to share personal stories from Missourians who have been hurt by the president’s health care law. I also called on my Senate colleagues to begin the process of repealing the law and paving the way for better solutions to expand access to quality, affordable health care.

Democrats have failed to live up to nearly every promise they made when they forced Obamacare through Congress without a single Republican vote. Now is the time for them to start making things right. They’ll have that opportunity today when the Senate considers a resolution that gives Congress the tools to repeal Obamacare and pave the way for solutions that will expand access to quality, affordable health care for all Americans.  http://bit.ly/2ikXt43

Early this morning the Senate passed a resolution that gives Congress the tools to repeal Obamacare and bring relief to families who are struggling with widespread premium hikes, skyrocketing deductibles, and dwindling health plan options. This is a critical step toward paving the way for solutions that will expand access to quality, affordable health care for all Americans.
Due to inclement weather, mobile offices scheduled for tomorrow in Rolla, Vienna and Jefferson City are postponed. Stay safe.

At a confirmation hearing held by the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence today, I questioned Rep. Mike Pompeo, President-elect Donald Trump’s nominee for CIA director, regarding cybersecurity issues, social media privacy, encryption, and how he plans to effectively work with the Director of National Intelligence.
Today, we honor Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr., whose legacy has inspired generations of Americans and will continue to for many years to come.
Today I gave MSNBC a behind-the-scenes look at planning the 58th Presidential Inauguration, a historic event that will be watched around the world.

During a confirmation hearing held by the Senate Commerce Committee, I questioned Wilbur Ross, President-elect Donald Trump’s nominee for Commerce Secretary, about his plan to improve our nation’s infrastructure and the impact it would have on creating more good-paying jobs in Missouri.
Enjoyed meeting with performers from Missouri State Chorale as they prepare to sing during the 58th Presidential Inauguration.
As Chairman of the @JCCIC, I had the honor of delivering the opening remarks during the 58th Presidential Inauguration.
Earlier today, I gave remarks to the new President, Vice President, and their families, at the Presidential Inaugural Luncheon.
President Trump has a great opportunity to establish a long-term view of what our nation’s courts, including the Supreme Court, should look like.

America is facing more threats, from more directions, than ever before. Rep. Mike Pompeo has the knowledge and experience to lead the CIA in carrying out its critical mission, and I was proud to vote for his confirmation today. It is imperative that the Senate acts quickly on all of the president’s national security nominees to ensure these agencies have the direction and leadership they need to keep Americans safe.
Today, the Senate Commerce Committee passed my anti-spoofing bill to better protect Missourians, especially seniors, from fraud and identity theft. Learn more here: http://bit.ly/2j1mVNK

I’m glad President Trump is wasting no time turning the page on eight years of the Obama administration’s failed energy policies by paving the way for the Keystone XL pipeline. The pipeline, which has long had the backing of the majority of Americans, will pump 800,000 barrels of oil a day to the United States, creating new jobs and bolstering our energy independence. I’ll continue working to advance an all-of-the-above energy policy that will create jobs and lower costs for families and small businesses in Missouri and across the nation. http://bit.ly/2kf9qqX

As the Chairman of the Joint Congressional Committee on Inaugural Ceremonies, I had the honor of planning and participating in the 58th Presidential Inauguration. As we have for over 200 years, our nation stood together with all three branches of our government to witness this commonplace and miraculous event in our enduring republic.

I always encourage constituents to contact me and share thoughts or concerns. Although my office is experiencing a high volume of phone calls, you can also voice your opinion by contacting me on Facebook, Twitter, or by visiting my website. I look forward to hearing from you. https://www.blunt.senate.gov/public/index.cfm/contact-roy

Spoke during Senate Republican Leadership stakeout today to urge my Senate Democratic colleagues to confirm President Trump’s cabinet selections and allow the government to be put in place. On this day in 2009, the Senate had confirmed the majority of President Obama’s cabinet-level nominees, along with several other senior government officials. By comparison, Senate Democrats have only allowed votes on five of President Trump’s nominees.

Judge Neil Gorsuch is a well-respected jurist with the experience and qualifications to serve on our nation’s highest court. In his decade on the 10th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals bench, he has demonstrated a steadfast commitment to upholding the rule of law and interpreting the Constitution as its authors intended. President Trump made the right choice in selecting Judge Gorsuch to begin shaping the long-term view of the court. http://www.blunt.senate.gov/public/index.cfm/2017/1/blunt-praises-nomination-of-judge-neil-gorsuch-to-serve-on-u-s-supreme-court

I believe Betsy DeVos understands that decisions about education need to be made much closer to where kids are. I look forward to working with her to find ways to get those decisions back to local school boards, and moms and dads. As Chairman of the Appropriations Subcommittee for the Department of Education, I will be working hard to ensure that public education continues to be appreciated as the cornerstone of opportunity in America.

Yesterday, I spoke on the Senate floor to support Judge Neil Gorsuch’s nomination to serve as an Associate Justice on the U.S. Supreme Court. Judge Gorsuch is deeply qualified and consistently demonstrates his commitment to upholding the rule of law and interpreting the Constitution as its authors intended.

Spoke during Senate leadership press conference earlier to discuss Senator Jeff Sessions’ qualifications and work on behalf of crime victims. I look forward to voting for his confirmation as U.S. Attorney General.

Yesterday I spoke on the Senate floor about my support for President Trump’s nominee to lead the Department of Health and Human Services, Dr. Tom Price. He is a man who has dedicated his life to improving health care, and there is no one better suited to take the helm at this department as we look to repeal and replace ObamaCare.

President Trump, like all presidents before him, has every right to put his stamp on the government as soon as possible. But, in an unprecedented manner, Senate Democrats are obstructing the process of confirming well-qualified Cabinet nominees.
Enjoyed sitting down with representatives of Children’s Mercy, Cardinal Glennon, and St. Louis Children’s Hospital to talk about ways to help sick kids receive the quality care they need and deserve.
There’s no question President Trump made the right choice in nominating Judge Gorsuch. Look forward to seeing him sworn in as the next Supreme Court justice.
On Missouri Military Appreciation Day, a special thank you to the brave men & women who work tirelessly to keep our nation safe.
NA
Spoke with a panel today during an Appropriations Subcommittee hearing to discuss mental health treatment & programs.

Excessive red tape handed down by Washington bureaucrats disproportionately harms rural America, especially when it comes to delivering quality health care. That’s why I joined my colleagues in sending a letter to HHS Secretary Price underscoring the unique challenges rural health care providers face, and urging him to work with us to help address these issues moving forward. http://www.blunt.senate.gov/public/index.cfm/2017/2/blunt-letter-to-hhs-secretary-price-stresses-need-for-quality-health-care-in-rural-missouri

Yesterday, I reintroduced legislation to make the New Market Tax Credit permanent. Over the past 17 years, this program has expanded opportunity and improved the quality of life in low-income rural and urban communities that need it most.  Here’s a look at how the NMTC has benefitted Missourians, and why I’m working to make sure it continues: http://www.blunt.senate.gov/public/index.cfm/2017/2/blunt-leads-bipartisan-effort-to-boost-economic-growth-create-jobs-in-low-income-rural-urban-communities

The story of our great nation cannot be fully told without the rich history of African Americans. I’m proud to support the creation of a commission to celebrate 400 years of African American culture, because America is a better nation when all our citizens learn more about our history. http://www.blunt.senate.gov/public/index.cfm/2017/2/blunt-kaine-warner-booker-reintroduce-commission-to-recognize-400-years-of-african-american-history

Senate Democrats continue to set new records with the time it takes to confirm the presidents’ well-qualified cabinet nominees. We need to get the government in place, and it’s time for them to quit standing in the way.
Whether it’s massive new energy regulations or the sweeping Waters of the U.S. Rule, the excessive red tape coming out of the EPA will drive up costs for families in our state and across the nation.

We shouldn’t let unnecessary red tape prevent kids with complex medical conditions from getting the specialized treatment they need. The ACE Kids Act will help relieve burdens on families by better coordinating treatment, making it possible for more kids in Missouri and across the nation get the quality care they deserve. http://bit.ly/2lVBrUY

The disgusting acts of vandalism at the Chesed Shel Emeth Cemetery are an affront to the values we hold dear as Americans. An attack against any faith compels all people of faith to come together in unyielding support for our neighbors, and unequivocal condemnation of the horrendous attack they have suffered. Together, we will make it clear to the perpetrators of this desecration that they have only strengthened our resolve to defend the rights of every faith and individual in our community. I extend my deepest condolences to the families that have been most directly affected by this attack, and thank the law enforcement personnel who are working to bring those responsible to justice.

America’s service members and veterans have the knowledge, skills and leadership training that provide a tremendous asset to private-sector employers. I’ve been encouraged to see employers in Missouri and across the nation working to expand opportunities for our military men and women as they transition to the civilian workforce. The bipartisan HIRE Vets Act, which I recently introduced, will help connect more veterans with the businesses that offer benefits and opportunities geared toward veterans’ hiring and career development, and give these businesses the recognition they deserve. http://bit.ly/2l0gre7

As new jobs emerge in areas like advanced technology and health care, community colleges will continue playing a critical role in preparing students for the 21st century economy. I’m honored to receive the National Education Service Award from the Association of Community College Trustees and American Association of Community Colleges, and I’ll continue working to make post-secondary education more affordable and accessible for students in our state and across the nation. bit.ly/2lPwBf7
Lieutenant Colonel Courtland is a great example of what it means to put on the uniform. I’m honored to have taken part in her promotion ceremony at Whiteman Air Force Base.

Historically Black Colleges and Universities offer a unique environment that provides students the foundation they need to succeed in their academic and post-academic careers. As chairman of the appropriations subcommittee that funds the Department of Education, I’ve been proud to support increasing resources for HBCUs and restoring year-round Pell Grants to help more students get the education they need to get ahead. I look forward to working with the president to achieve the goals laid out in his Executive Order on HBCUs.

The WOTUS rule is a prime example of Washington bureaucrats run amok under the Obama administration, and it needs to go. I’ve heard from countless farmers, ranchers, small businesses owners, and elected officials in Missouri who have said this rule will drive up costs and make it impossible for them to do their jobs. I’m grateful that President Trump is taking swift action to protect Missourians, and all Americans, from the fallout of this reckless EPA power grab.

President Trump is taking action to fulfill the commitments he made to the American people. In his remarks this evening, the president laid out an agenda focused on expanding economic opportunity, improving education, and protecting communities. I look forward to working with the administration to move forward on solutions that reflect the priorities of Missourians and families across our nation. http://www.blunt.senate.gov/public/index.cfm/2017/2/blunt-commends-president-trump-s-commitment-to-fulfilling-promises-to-the-american-people

We cannot continue allowing U.S. taxpayer dollars to be used by the Palestinian Authority to reward convicted terrorists and their families for acts of violence against Israel or the United States. Under current Palestinian Authority law, the more heinous an act of terror an individual commits, the greater the reward. This is an outrageous policy and I urge my Senate colleagues to support this effort to end the Palestinian Authority’s unconscionable law.
My thoughts are with the families in Southeast Missouri who were impacted by the deadly storms. My staff is in contact with local officials and here to help: (573) 334-7044.

Attorney General Jeff Sessions has said he had no discussions with Russian officials regarding the election, and I take him at his word. As part of the ongoing Senate Intelligence Committee’s investigation into reports of Russian involvement in U.S. elections, I intend to go to CIA headquarters in the next week to look at all the documents and reports myself.
The partnership between the National Park Service & CityArchRiver ensures that the #GatewayArch will continue to be a welcoming destination for millions of visitors every year.

Extending the hours of the Salem VA clinic is an important step to removing the obstacles preventing our nation’s heroes from getting the high-quality health care treatment they earned and deserve. Thank you for this recognition, American Legion Walker-Roney Post 99.

U.S. Army Fort Leonard Wood and the community are fortunate to have Major General Savre’s leadership as we continue working together on FLW priorities, like the long-term future of General Leonard Wood Army Community Hospital (GLWACH).

As chairman of the appropriations subcommittee that funds the National Institutes of Health, I was proud to secure the first major funding increase for NIH medical research in over a decade. We need to continue responsibly investing in medical research to find new cures, improve the quality of life for patients and their families, and drive down health care costs over the long term. While it’s impossible to know what scientific advances will be made in the next ten years, we do know that further investments in NIH research will lead to more life-saving breakthroughs.

Mark from Blue Springs, MO told me there’s “nothing affordable about the Affordable Care Act” when it comes to the skyrocketing premiums and deductibles his family is facing under the law.  That’s why we’re working to repeal and replace Obamacare with patient-centered reforms that will allow Americans to choose the plans and doctors that best fit their needs and budgets.

Obamacare is wreaking havoc on our health care system and leaving Missourians with higher costs, fewer options and more uncertainty. In my Kansas City Star op-ed, I highlighted Republican solutions that would go a long way toward improving and expanding access to affordable health care for families in Missouri and across the nation.

Providing students with high-quality education in STEM will give workers the training they need to find good-paying jobs in areas like manufacturing, health research, and cybersecurity. With the number of STEM-related jobs continuing to grow, investing in STEM today will go a long way toward ensuring our nation’s workforce can compete in a 21st Century economy.
Judge Gorsuch is a great nominee who interprets the Constitution as the founders intended. #ConfirmGorsuch

Today, the U.S. Army announced that Fort Leonard Wood's Basic Combat Training mission is expected to increase by about 4,500 soldiers this year. I’m proud that even more men and women will become soldiers in our state, and I’ll continue backing efforts to ensure our military branches have the end strength they need to fulfill their missions. https://www.blunt.senate.gov/public/index.cfm/2017/3/blunt-applauds-expansion-of-basic-combat-training-mission-at-fort-leonard-wood

The Supreme Court is one of the most important legacies this president is likely to leave, and he made the right choice in selecting Judge Gorsuch to begin shaping the long-term view of the court. From receiving praise from many Senate Democrats to earning the American Bar Association’s highest rating, Judge Gorsuch’s lifetime of service has undoubtedly prepared him to become the nation’s next Supreme Court justice.

Each year, nearly 200,000 service members transition from active duty to civilian life. These men and women have the skills and experience that are an asset to employers in every sector of our economy. My HIRE Vets Act, which passed the Senate yesterday, will help connect more veterans with businesses that offer benefits and opportunities to help them succeed.

The military has evolved over the past decades, and the policies affecting their families should as well. That’s why I was glad to speak with Defense Secretary James Mattis and Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff General Joseph Dunford today about my Military Family Stability Act. This bill would help military families by allowing them to either stay at their current duty station or move early to better manage a move that cuts a school year or professional obligation.

A child is diagnosed with cancer every three minutes, and one out of every eight who are diagnosed will lose their life to the disease. As chairman of the appropriations subcommittee that funds the National Cancer Institute, I have prioritized resources for pediatric oncology research and clinical trials for children, and pressed NCI to research needs, outcomes, and barriers faced by pediatric cancer survivors.  The STAR Act, which I’m proud to cosponsor, will expand my efforts on pediatric cancer research and help improve the quality of life for childhood cancer survivors. Learn more about the bill here:

Throughout the Senate Judiciary Committee’s confirmation hearings, Supreme Court nominee Judge Gorsuch has demonstrated the integrity, professional qualifications, and judicial temperament to serve on the nation’s highest court. #ConfirmGorsuch

Missouri families are facing significant increases in their utility bills under the EPA’s out-of-control energy regulations, and relief can’t come soon enough. President Trump’s Executive Order, which begins dismantling these excessive regulations, is an important step toward protecting low and middle-income Americans who can least afford higher costs on everything from gas to groceries.

Judge Gorsuch’s performance during last week’s confirmation hearings leaves no doubt that he is qualified to serve on our nation’s highest court. Throughout his career, he has shown independence, integrity, and a mainstream judicial philosophy that make him a worthy successor to Justice Scalia. There’s no precedent for requiring a 60-vote threshold to confirm a Supreme Court nominee, and Judge Gorsuch hasn’t given Senate Democrats any reason to require one now. I look forward to voting in favor of his confirmation.

We must have judges on all our federal courts, especially the Supreme Court, who understand that they are not politicians in robes. Their job is to determine what the law and the Constitution says - not what they think it should say. Judge Gorsuch is that kind of judge.

It’s an incredible honor to receive the 2017 Distinguished Public Service Award from the American Association for Cancer Research. As chairman of the appropriations subcommittee that funds NIH, I’ll continue working to establish a pattern of responsibly investing in groundbreaking medical research that will save lives and drive down health care costs.

The Delta Queen is a remarkable part of our nation’s history, and I’m thrilled that it is another step closer to making its way back to Missouri and once again cruising the Mississippi. Restoring the Delta Queen to full operation will create jobs, support economic growth, and enhance our state’s tourism industry.

The century-old Riverside Bridge in Ozark has been closed for five of the last seven years. The most recent closure, dating back to July of 2015, is adding to emergency response times, hurting local businesses, and making it difficult for area residents to get around. My new bill will help expedite the construction of a new bridge, which will provide a long-term solution to the frequent closures.

In my column in the Springfield Business Journal, I highlighted Judge Gorsuch’s experience, bipartisan support, and judicial philosophy to make the case that he is the right pick for the Supreme Court. I look forward to supporting Judge Gorsuch’s confirmation, and hope my colleagues on both sides of the aisle will do the same.

The relationship between the Waynesville-St. Robert Regional Airport at Fort Leonard Wood and Lambert International Airport in St. Louis is an example of how small and non-hub airports provide a vital connection to larger airports, which in turn supports local businesses, promotes tourism, and allows Americans to reach more destinations nationwide.

Judge Gorsuch has made clear that the role of a judge is to rule on the law as it is written, not as he or she thinks it should be written. His confirmation to the Supreme Court is a victory for every American who believes the Constitution should be read and applied as our founders intended, and I look forward to seeing him sworn in.

Thank you to Missouri State University College of Agriculture for hosting the 2017 Agriculture Forum. I’ll keep working to make sure our current and future Missouri farmers have the tools they need to take advantage of the great economic opportunities ahead.

During my tour of Mo-Sci Corporation in Rolla, I learned more about how this innovative company works closely with Missouri S&T and Washington University in St. Louis to develop high-tech products for various industries.
It was great to join National Park Service and CityArchRiver leaders to check in on construction of this national treasure and model public-private partnership.
Happy Easter Sunday to you and your family.

Today, the Supreme Court will hear oral arguments in a case involving Trinity Lutheran Church of Columbia, Missouri. I’m proud to stand with Trinity Lutheran and share their belief that the government shouldn’t be able to categorically deny benefits to a religious organization simply because they are religious. I’m hopeful the Supreme Court will reach the same conclusion in this case, which will have a lasting impact on Americans’ right to religious liberty.

Today, I announced that Missouri has been awarded a $10 million opioid crisis grant. In 2015, more than 1,000 Missourians died from a lethal drug overdose. Addiction is treatable, but only around ten percent of those struggling with the disease get the help they need. This funding will expand access to treatment, recovery, and prevention programs, and strengthen our state’s ability to combat this growing epidemic. As chairman of the appropriations subcommittee that funds the Department of Health and Human Services, I was proud to secure funding for this grant program in last year’s short-term government funding bill, and will continue working to prioritize resources to address the opioid crisis.

Today, I welcomed EPA Administrator Scott Pruitt to Missouri to hear firsthand about the devastating impact the Waters of the United States rule and the so-called Clean Power Plan would have on energy producers, farmers, ranchers, and Missouri families. President Trump and Administrator Pruitt have wasted no time in dismantling these excessive regulations and keeping their promise to the American people to promote a true all-of-the-above energy policy. I’ll continue supporting them in that effort. http://bit.ly/2pWPQ4I

Today, I introduced two measures honoring our nation’s military service members who were injured or became ill while serving, and their family members. We would not have the blessings of freedom that we do without the sacrifices they have made. The first measure I introduced would designate May 1, 2017 as Silver Star Service Banner Day this year, and the second would make it a national day marked on May 1 every year. https://www.blunt.senate.gov/public/index.cfm/news?ID=5FD2B4BE-10DD-4726-9A59-A0C8A8E0F922

This week, I re-introduced a bill to make adoption more affordable for hardworking families by making the current adoption tax credit fully refundable. I’m encouraged by the bipartisan support we’ve received for this bill and, as co-chair of the Congressional Coalition on Adoption, I’ll continue advancing policies that help connect children in need of homes with families that are eager to adopt. https://www.blunt.senate.gov/public/index.cfm/2017/4/blunt-casey-introduce-legislation-to-make-adoption-tax-credit-fully-refundable

My thoughts are with all of the families and communities that have been affected by the widespread flooding in our state. I am grateful for all of the first responders and emergency management personnel who are working around the clock to keep people safe. With dangerous conditions expected to continue, and additional areas at risk, I will continue being in close contact with Governor Greitens, and state and local officials, to monitor the situation. While we do not yet know the full extent of the damage, I stand ready to advocate for any federal assistance that may be needed once those assessments are made.

Responsible investments in NIH research will pave the way for new treatments and cures, reduce health care costs over the long term, and maintain America’s competitive edge in innovation. That’s why I’m proud to announce another $2 billion funding increase for NIH, which will help give hope to more families battling cancer, Alzheimer’s disease, and other chronic diseases. http://bit.ly/2pxAYuy

As a former history teacher and university president, I’m committed to helping more people get the education they need to get ahead. That’s why I’m proud to announce that the government funding bill, which has just been introduced and is expected to be considered by the Senate this week, restores year-round Pell Grants. This has been one of my priorities as chairman of the appropriations subcommittee that funds the Department of Education, and is a critical step toward making college more affordable for hardworking students in Missouri and across the nation. http://bit.ly/2pxhLJt

Missouri is home to more than 45,000 military and civilian defense personnel who play an integral role in keeping our nation safe. This week, the Senate is expected to take up a bill that provides the resources they need to carry out their mission. The measure also funds defense health programs and military pay and benefits, including a pay raise for all military personnel. http://bit.ly/2pz2pEg

Whether it’s physical or behavioral health, children have a unique set of health care needs and we’re facing a significant shortage of providers who are able to meet them. Legislation I reintroduced will make it more affordable for health care providers to pursue a pediatric subspecialty and, in turn, expand childrens’ access to care. http://bit.ly/2qwgSAf
Strengthening our military is a national priority and the government funding bill reflects that. Watch more from my interview this morning with Fox News.

Each year, nearly 200,000 service members transition from active duty to civilian life, and finding the right opportunity in the private sector can prove challenging. Today, the Senate passed my HIRE Vets Act, which will help connect more veterans with employers that recognize the unique value they bring to the job. I’m glad we were able to send this measure to the president’s desk and take another step toward fulfilling our promises to those who have served. http://bit.ly/2qJrMCE

Today, the Senate passed a bill that funds key Missouri priorities while eliminating or streamlining dozens of ineffective or duplicative programs. The bill strengthens our nation’s defense and focuses resources on programs that provide the most benefit to the most people, like NIH medical research. I’m glad to see it on its way to the president’s desk. http://bit.ly/2qJOTgz
Today, I spoke on the Senate floor to commend President Trump’s Executive Order that takes important steps to strengthen religious freedom protections.
On NBC’s Meet the Press this morning, I discussed the failures of Obamacare and the path forward on repealing and replacing the law to expand access to quality health care.
My office is now accepting applications from young Missourians who wish to attend a U.S. Military Service Academy: http://bit.ly/2pdMQVv

Discussed the widespread failures of Obamacare this morning on Fox News’ Happening Now. With less access and higher premiums, it’s clear the current system is just not serving Americans well and it has to be changed.

Director Comey has served the country well in a number of different roles. Many, including myself, have questioned his actions more than once over the past year. I believe new leadership at the FBI will restore confidence in the organization and among the people who do the hard work to carry out its mission.
As we recognize Mental Health Month, we’re reminded that there’s plenty of more work to be done to reach our goal of treating behavioral health like all other health.

Today, I spoke on the Senate floor to mark National Police Week and pay tribute to three Missouri law enforcement officers killed in the line of duty this past year. Our prayers remain with the families of these fallen heroes.

Families are the backbone of our military. Making it easier for them to manage the challenges that come with military life is both a readiness and retention issue. That’s why I just reintroduced the Military Family Stability Act, which would help address one of the major challenges I hear from military families: an ill-timed move that takes a child out of school or prevents a husband or wife from pursuing an educational or career opportunity. https://www.blunt.senate.gov/public/index.cfm/2017/5/senators-blunt-gillibrand-representatives-wilson-davis-introduce-military-family-stability-act

Missouri is a transportation hub, and improving our roads, bridges, and waterways is critical for economic growth in our state and across the nation. The BRIDGE Act, which I reintroduced yesterday, is a bipartisan bill that will provide much-needed resources to strengthen infrastructure and help ensure Missouri’s farmers, manufacturers, and small businesses are able to remain competitive in an increasingly global economy. https://www.blunt.senate.gov/public/index.cfm/2017/5/blunt-warner-team-up-again-to-improve-infrastructure-nationwide

Every child deserves a permanent, safe, loving home no matter where they are born. Unfortunately, there are millions of children across the world who are growing up without the security and stability that comes with family-based care. That’s why I reintroduced a bill to help connect more children in need of permanent homes with families in the United States and around the world that are eager to adopt. https://www.blunt.senate.gov/public/index.cfm/2017/5/senators-blunt-klobuchar-representatives-granger-lawrence-introduce-vulnerable-children-and-families-act
Congratulations to the graduates of Missouri State’s Department of Defense & Strategic Studies program. I’m very proud of what they’ve accomplished and wish them the best.
During events in Arnold and Eureka yesterday, I heard from local leaders and emergency personnel about how flood recovery efforts are impacting local schools, families, and small businesses.
NA

Obamacare is collapsing and Missouri families are paying the price. With today’s announcement from Blue Cross Blue Shield of Kansas City, we now have tens of thousands of families that have lost their plans and have no insurer option on the exchanges next year. The status quo is unacceptable, and it is unsustainable. That’s why I’ll continue working to advance solutions that will provide more options, better access, greater stability, and lower costs for Missouri families. http://bit.ly/2qh0Fz5

No parent should have to worry that their child is growing up in an unsafe or unhealthy environment. West Lake families have waited far too long for a solution to this issue, and it’s imperative that we look at all options necessary to expedite clean-up efforts. I’ll continue working with my colleagues, federal agencies, and local leaders to determine the best path forward to give families the peace of mind they deserve. http://bit.ly/2qXnc5d

When you’re battling cancer and you lose access to the doctors you know and trust, no reasonable person could argue the system we have is working. Obamacare has clearly failed, and that’s why I’ll continue working to help families that are facing higher costs, fewer health plan options, and less access to quality health care under the law.

Sent a letter to President Trump today supporting Governor Eric Greitens’ request for a disaster declaration for 45 Missouri counties impacted by severe storms and historic flooding. I’ll continue working with the governor, my congressional colleagues, and the administration to ensure Missourians have the resources they need to recover and rebuild. http://bit.ly/2r23wPy
NA

Congratulations to the Missourians who accepted appointments to attend our nation’s service academies. These men and women have distinguished themselves in their schools and communities, and I have no doubt they will do the same in their military careers. http://bit.ly/2qFXfpB
Today on Fox News Sunday, I discussed the recent terror attacks in London and Manchester, and the ongoing threats facing the United States and our allies.

This week, I led a bipartisan delegation of senators in a visit to NIH headquarters to learn more about the agency’s work to develop life-saving treatments and cures. I’ve been proud to lead efforts to increase federal investments in medical research, and will continue working to ensure NIH has the resources it needs to give hope to families battling cancer, Alzheimer’s disease, and other chronic diseases.

As the oldest town in Missouri, Ste. Genevieve is a fundamental part of our state and nation’s rich history. That’s why I introduced legislation to establish Ste. Genevieve as a national park, which will underscore its significant historic value and attract more visitors from across the nation who want to experience a taste of French colonial life. http://bit.ly/2re8YMk

Today, I introduced bipartisan legislation to help more low-income Americans expand their education, save for the future, and reach their goal of becoming financially independent. Learn more: http://bit.ly/2s7lW01
Spoke on the Senate floor to honor the brave U.S. Capitol Police and local law enforcement officers who responded to today’s attack.

Iran is the world’s number one state sponsor of terrorism and continues violating international agreements with its ballistic missile tests and illegal arms transfers. Today, the Senate overwhelmingly passed legislation, which I cosponsored, to expand sanctions on Iran and hold the regime accountable.

I appreciate Defense Secretary James Mattis and Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff General Joseph Dunford’s help with my Military Family Stability Act. With their backing, I’m hopeful that we can get this bill to the president’s desk this year.  Here’s more from yesterday’s Defense Appropriations Subcommittee hearing: http://bit.ly/2rlzqnt

Beginning July 1, college students will once again be eligible for year-round Pell Grants. As chairman of the appropriations subcommittee that funds the Department of Education, restoring year-round Pell has been one of my top priorities. I appreciate President Trump signing year-round Pell into law earlier this year, and encourage students in Missouri and across the country to take advantage of this opportunity. http://bit.ly/2syaHxy

Obamacare is imploding. In Missouri, premiums on the Obamacare exchanges have increased by 145 percent, on average, since 2013, and 25 counties may have no provider offering health insurance on the Obamacare exchanges next year.  More from yesterday’s Republican leadership press conference: http://bit.ly/2sBW3W5

Year after year, Missouri families have had to worry about their health plans being canceled, their options and access being taken away, and their premiums going up. In our state, 25 counties have no companies willing to offer health care coverage on the exchanges next year and premiums are up 145 percent, on average, since 2013. The status quo is far from what was promised and it is unsustainable.  The draft health care legislation preserves access to care for people with pre-existing conditions, strengthens Medicaid and does not change Medicare, gives people more health insurance choices, and allows people to stay on their family health insurance plan until they are 26.   Members of both parties will have an opportunity to offer amendments as the process moves forward. I will carefully review the final legislation with a focus on how it will help address the problems Missourians are facing under Obamacare. American families need a more reliable and affordable health care system, and this bill takes important steps in that direction.

The VA accountability bill that President Trump signed into law today is an important step to increase accountability at the VA and ensure its employees are helping veterans get the care and benefits they’ve earned. I was proud to have cosponsored the bill, and I’ll continue working to fulfill the promises we have made to those who have served. http://bit.ly/2rLcnCS

I’m pleased the Supreme Court ruled today that the government cannot categorically deny benefits to Trinity Lutheran of Columbia, Missouri, or any religious organization, simply because they are religious. This decision marks a key victory for Americans’ right to religious liberty, a fundamental freedom that we have enjoyed for more than 220 years. http://bit.ly/2sT1QXB
The Trump administration’s withdrawal of the #WOTUS rule is a huge win for Missouri farmers, ranchers, and small business owners. My statement: http://bit.ly/2sYHWdR

Yesterday, I questioned Labor Secretary Alexander Acosta about progress in implementing the HIRE Vets Act.  The measure, which I introduced earlier this year and was signed into law last month, will help connect more veterans with employers that recognize the unique value they bring to the job. http://bit.ly/2s2Ndj3

Firefighters and first responders put themselves in harm’s way to save lives, and it’s critical that they have access to the training and equipment that will help them do their jobs as safely as possible. The new grant funding announced today will help ensure local agencies have the federal support they need: http://bit.ly/2s5YwHh

Today, the Senate Commerce Committee approved the Federal Aviation Administration reauthorization bill, which includes several key priorities. The bill will help improve the safety and reliability of air travel, protect access to small and rural airports, and ensure our nation’s aviation industry remains competitive in the 21st Century global economy. Read more: http://bit.ly/2t69JsC
Proud to announce that NGA West facility is one step closer to breaking ground in #STL: http://bit.ly/2s765gX

Today, we celebrate the birth of our nation and principles on which it was founded: the right to life, liberty and the pursuit of happiness. Our men and women in uniform put themselves in harm’s way to defend those inalienable rights. We are incredibly grateful for their service and for the sacrifices they have made, and continue to make, to secure our freedom.
Congrats, Jeremy! This Springfield teen hit 8 home runs in last night’s Junior Home Run Derby. (via Springfield News-Leader)

Replacing the Riverside Bridge is a long-term solution to the flood-related closures that are hurting local businesses, increasing emergency response times, and making daily life difficult for families in the community. I’m glad this bill is another step closer to becoming law, and I urge my colleagues to support it when it makes it to the Senate floor.

Yesterday, I questioned a panel during a Senate Commerce Committee hearing to learn more about public and private sector efforts to combat human trafficking. As Chairman of the Senate Appropriations Subcommittee on Labor, Health and Human Services, Education, and Related Agencies, I’ve been proud to secure increased resources for the Victims of Trafficking program.

President Trump was sworn in seven months ago and he has every right to put his administration in place. Unfortunately he hasn’t been able to do that because Senate Democrats are engaging in an unprecedented level of obstruction. At the current rate, it will take more than 11 years to confirm all of the nominations that require Senate confirmation.

Yesterday, the Senate Appropriations Committee unanimously approved a military construction and VA funding bill that includes key resources to improve veterans’ health care and help ensure Missouri continues to play a vital role in defending the nation.

A peaceful transition of power shows the world democracy in action. I was honored & humbled to lead the Joint Congressional Committee on Inaugural Ceremonies last year and to work alongside Capitol Police to keep everyone safe on Inauguration Day. I’m proud to receive the Honor Badge from Capitol Police Chief Verderosa.

Very happy that Welcome Home, Inc. opened its doors in Columbia today. Our veterans protected our freedom, and they should never be left without a home or the support they need. Welcome Home Inc. will provide veterans with shelter and services to help them adjust to civilian life.

American manufacturing accounts for 12.3 million jobs in our country, including more than 260,000 in Missouri. Products that are grown and made in America create a stronger economy for hardworking families. I will continue advancing policies aimed at improving our infrastructure, curbing excessive regulations, and creating a foundation for stronger growth in the manufacturing sector.

Obamacare has left Missouri families with higher costs, fewer options, and less access to quality healthcare.  I’m glad that the Senate today voted to move forward with debate on the House-passed bill to repeal and replace Obamacare.  All senators will now have the opportunity to offer amendments and look at ways we can improve the final product. My hope is that we will be able to find common ground on solutions that meet the needs of Missourians, and create a more stable and reliable health care system.

Our nation was founded on the principle of religious liberty, and we have a unique responsibility to protect and promote that fundamental freedom throughout the world. The appointment of an Ambassador-at-Large for International Religious Freedom at the State Department sends a clear message to those who are struggling to secure their religious liberty that we stand with them, and it will be a priority in our foreign policy. http://bit.ly/2vMVPgf

Maintaining choice and competition amongst student loan servicers is the best way to ensure they will continue improving services for student borrowers. Learn more about the bipartisan Student Loan Servicer Performance Accountability Act that I introduced yesterday ⬇️

Websites that turn a profit off the sexual exploitation of trafficking victims should not be afforded protection under the Communications Decency Act, which is why I was proud to join a bipartisan group of senators to introduce the Stop Enabling Sex Traffickers Act. This bill makes narrow but critical changes to the law to better protect victims and hold perpetrators accountable

39% of the rural population across the country lack access to broadband, and in rural Missouri it’s 61%. Expanding broadband access in our state will enhance the quality of education, benefit farmers and ranchers, and improve access to healthcare.

Today, the Senate dealt a huge blow to the criminals who use spoofing scams to deceive, intimidate, and defraud victims, especially seniors. Learn more about my efforts to better protect all Missourians from these spoofing scams here ⬇️

Ozark families, small business owners, and emergency responders have all been negatively impacted by the frequent, flood-related closures of the Riverside Bridge. The Senate passed my bill to expedite replacement of the bridge, bringing us one step closer to a permanent solution. More here ⬇️

Exciting health research is being done right here in Missouri at Washington University in St. Louis. I visited campus with National Center for Advancing Translational Sciences Director Dr. Austin to discuss the impact federal investment is having on the groundbreaking research that’s underway in our state.
On this day in 1821, Missouri became the 24th state to join the Union.
Yesterday I joined Jamie Allman in St. Louis to discuss North Korea and the president's response to recent threats. View here ⬇️

#TBT Visiting Wilson’s Creek National Battlefield. Today is the 156th anniversary of the Battle of Wilson’s Creek, the first major Civil War battle fought west of the Mississippi River. As a former history teacher, I’d like to thank the National Park Service for preserving our past so future generations can tour and learn.

Missourian Arla Harrell fought the VA for years to receive treatment after being subjected to mustard gas experiments in WWII. Yesterday, President Trump signed the Arla Harrell Act into law, which will help ensure World War II heroes, like Arla, receive the acknowledgement, assistance, and care they deserve.

Nearly 2/3 of rural Missourians don’t have access to broadband. That needs to change.    I spoke with the Missouri Farm Bureau at the Missouri State Fair today on the importance of expanding broadband access to rural Missouri. You can watch my full remarks here ⬇️  http://bit.ly/2vH7nDt

In 2017, it is unacceptable that 61 percent of rural Missourians lack access to broadband. As a member of the Senate Commerce Committee, I’m committed to ending the digital divide and ensuring rural communities have the same opportunities to grow, compete, and succeed. Learn more in my latest op-ed: http://bit.ly/2vjQBYB

The U.S. Government Accountability Office (GAO) released a report today that validates the National Geospatial-Intelligence Agency's site selection process for their new West HQ in North St. Louis.   As a member of the Intelligence and Appropriations Committees, I’ve consistently advocated for funding for this new facility and am happy this GAO report keeps the momentum for this important NGA project going.   You can read my full statement and the GAO report here ⬇️

It was great to join students, faculty, and local leaders for an event at Crowder College to celebrate the MARET Center’s 5th anniversary. I’m proud to support the center and the critical work they’re doing to develop cutting-edge research that is helping our nation move toward a true all-of-the above energy policy.
Today, I toured the Jordan Valley Community Health Center in Springfield to learn more about how they’re improving behavioral and mental health treatment.

Today, I joined Chuck Todd on NBC’s Meet The Press to discuss North Korea’s latest nuclear test, the federal government’s response to Hurricane Harvey, and the need to provide tax relief for American families.

It’s been too long since working families saw the kind of change in their take-home pay that makes a difference. That’s why we need tax cuts and pro-growth policies that will strengthen our economy, boost wages, and help Missouri families get ahead. Read more from my op-ed in today’s Kansas City Star: https://www.blunt.senate.gov/public/index.cfm/2017/9/blunt-op-ed-in-kansas-city-star-families-and-small-business-need-tax-relief

My full statement on the Trump Administration’s DACA announcement ⬇️  The young people in the DACA program need a permanent, commonsense solution that will allow them to continue working and going to school in the only country that many of them have ever known. The manner in which this program was created has left DACA recipients in legal limbo for too long, and Congress now has a responsibility to work toward a legislative solution. At the same time, it is imperative that we continue working with the president to strengthen our border security. Enhancing our border security will help facilitate progress toward addressing all aspects of our broken immigration system.

For the second year in a row, the appropriations subcommittee that I chair has successfully worked together to craft a bipartisan bill that protects taxpayer dollars and prioritizes resources for programs that will have the most benefit for the most Missourians.  The subcommittee-passed funding bill includes another $2 billion increase for the National Institutes of Health (NIH), amounting to a 20 percent increase over the past three years. The bill also makes critical investments in efforts to combat the opioid epidemic, and increases the maximum Pell Grant award to make college more affordable for Missouri students. More on the Missouri priorities in the bill here ⬇️

Investing in NIH research gives doctors and researchers additional resources to help them treat and cure the most deadly and costliest diseases, including Alzheimer’s. That’s why, as chair of the appropriations subcommittee that oversees NIH funding, I’m proud to announce that the NIH is one step closer to receiving its third consecutive $2 billion increase. I’m glad the Appropriations Committee has voted to advance this bipartisan bill, and I urge my Senate colleagues to support the measure when it reaches the floor. http://bit.ly/2wcfcOs

Establishing a pattern of sustained investments in National Institutes of Health (NIH) medical research will provide researchers and scientists more resources to pursue new treatments and cures for our nation’s most costly and deadly diseases.

Missouri veterans gathered this morning at the Vietnam Veterans Memorial to send off an American flag and POW/MIA flag, which were flown over the Memorial. These flags are now on a cross-country trip to the new Missouri’s National Veterans Memorial Park in Perryville.    The park will be home to the nation’s first permanent, full-scale replica of the Vietnam Veterans Memorial.

This morning, it was an honor to join cancer survivors, advocates, and researchers to receive an award from the American Cancer Society Cancer Action Network - ACS CAN. As chairman of the appropriations subcommittee that funds the Department of Health and Human Services, I’ve been proud to lead efforts to increase resources for medical research at the National Institutes of Health (NIH), which will help accelerate progress in developing new treatments and cures for our nation’s mostly deadly diseases, including cancer. Over the past three years, funding for NIH has increased by 20 percent and funding for the National Cancer Institute has increased by 18 percent.

During a press conference with Republican leaders yesterday, I urged my colleagues to support the National Defense Authorization Act, which includes my bipartisan Military Family Stability Act.  The Military Family Stability Act would increase flexibility for military families by allowing them to either move early or remain at their current duty station for up to six months while their spouse begins a new assignment.   http://bit.ly/2wWsG5K

The family of Anthony Lamar Smith suffered a tragic loss. This is a difficult day for them, and for all St. Louisans who sought a different outcome in this case.   The response to this verdict will have a lasting impact not just on the community, but the country. Every American has the right to protest peacefully, and should have no doubt that right will be protected.   However, if this verdict is met with violence and destruction, it will do nothing but reignite the fear and anger that law enforcement and community leaders have worked tirelessly to address since Ferguson.   If it is met with a renewed commitment to continuing the work that is needed to rebuild trust between law enforcement and those they serve, it will show the world how we, as Americans, move forward.

This morning on Fox News Sunday, I highlighted the need to strengthen border security and pursue tax changes that will boost take-home pay for hardworking families. I also discussed the unrest in St. Louis and underscored the need to continue working to bring communities together.

Houses of worship provide vital support services during natural disasters, including food, comfort, shelter, and much more. That’s why I introduced legislation that would allow houses of worship to apply for disaster assistance on the exact same terms as other non-profits.

Under Obamacare, Missouri families have seen their premiums skyrocket, on average, 145 percent since 2013. Yesterday, I cosponsored the Healthcare Tax Relief Act to help protect families from an Obamacare tax that will drive costs up even further.

Victims of abuse and domestic violence deserve to feel safe and protected in their own homes. That’s why I’m proud to introduce the SAFE at Home Act, a bipartisan bill to strengthen privacy protections for victims of domestic violence. Click here to learn more about how this bill will help reduce violence and keep families safe.   http://bit.ly/2wYfxK9

More than half a million Missourians rely on community health centers, especially in our rural areas. That’s why I’ve just introduced legislation that will ensure community health centers have the resources they need to stay open and continue providing critical, affordable health care services.

Senator Stabenow and I joined together to introduce a bill to expand access to community-based mental health and addiction services. This bipartisan legislation would mark a significant step toward our goal of treating mental health like all other health in this country.   http://bit.ly/2xgB1gu

Yesterday, I spoke on the Senate floor in support of changes to the tax code that would allow Americans to keep more of their hard-earned income, create more high-paying jobs, and increase U.S. competitiveness. http://bit.ly/2y3GgEt
I commend President Trump for following through on his promise to restore and protect the religious freedom and conscience rights of all Americans.

Today, EPA Administrator Scott Pruitt announced that the Trump administration will put a stop to the previous administration’s excessive energy regulations, which could have left Missourians with double-digit utility bill hikes. This is great news for Missouri families, farmers, manufacturers, and energy producers, and I’ll continue working with the administration to advance a true all-of-the-above energy policy. https://www.blunt.senate.gov/public/index.cfm/2017/10/blunt-end-of-excessive-energy-regulations-provides-major-relief-for-missourians

As one of eight states participating in the Excellence in Mental Health Act pilot program, Missouri is leading the country in improving and expanding access to mental and behavioral health treatment.    I visited several community health centers and certified community behavioral health clinics around Missouri this week to see what is working and how we can work together to ensure mental health is treated like all other health.    Thank you to the medical professionals and staff at Swope Health Services, Burrell Center, the Ozark Center, Family Care Health Center, Northeast Missouri Health Council, the Community Health Center of Central Missouri, and the Family Guidance Center. Your insights are vital as we work to expand the Excellence in Mental Health Act program and I look forward to keeping the conversation going.

After visiting community health centers & certified community behavioral health clinics across Missouri, I’m proud  to see firsthand how our state is leading the country when it comes to improving services for mental and behavioral health. Innovation is happening right here.

One in four Americans will experience a mental or behavioral health issue in their lifetime, but only a fraction are able to get the help they need. That’s why it’s critical that we treat mental health like all other health in this country.
Happy Missouri Day - proud to be a 5th generation Missourian & honored to represent the Show Me State

Bill & Virginia Leffen Center for Autism opened its doors in 2007 with a preschool program. A decade later, they’ve expanded their services to reach more individuals on the autism spectrum. The center has helped individuals with autism build the skills they need to transition into mainstream classrooms and to have a more independent future. Their work truly changes lives and I’m honored to be here to celebrate their 10th anniversary. Look forward to seeing what the next 10 years bring.

Kayla was abused by her boyfriend but feared she would be stalked if she ended the relationship. Her story demonstrates why the SAFE At Home Act is critical to protecting victims of domestic abuse: http://bit.ly/2hZPyr9

Earlier today I had the opportunity to meet the Honor Flight of the Ozarks at the World War II Memorial. Honor Flight is a moving tribute to the sacrifices these brave men and women made and gives our veterans the recognition they deserve. It was wonderful to see such a large group of veterans from Springfield today and thank them for their service to our country. And thank you to all the organizers and guardians who helped make today possible.
As President Trump made clear today, providing tax cuts for hardworking Missouri families is a top priority  http://bit.ly/2h5uRe0

This week in 1861, the Pony Express closed after 19 months of delivering letters from St. Joseph to Sacramento. In that short time, Pony Express riders delivered approximately 35,000 letters between Missouri and California.
Our complicated tax code is ‘goblin’ up your hard-earned money.
Did you see Joe Niemeyer Jr. sing the national anthem at Monday’s St. Louis Blues game? Besides being a passionate singer, Joe has also represented Missouri in the Special Olympics.
Innovation is happening right here in our state. We’re moving forward on efforts to treat mental health like all other health care in this country.

Senate Democrats’ obstruction of President Trump’s well-qualified judicial nominees is unacceptable. That’s why I spoke on the Senate floor to urge my colleagues to quickly confirm pending federal judicial nominations, including Justice David Stras whose nomination to the 8th Circuit Court of Appeals, which includes Missouri, has been stalled. http://bit.ly/2AcwVsE

Every 68 seconds someone in America develops Alzheimer’s disease. This disease impacts not just the person who has it, but also the people who care about them. That’s why I’ve worked to prioritize resources for NIH research to advance progress toward a cure for Alzheimer’s.    http://bit.ly/2hARLKn
Helping families keep more of what they earn is a top priority when it comes to tax reform. Watch my interview with Fox News to learn more ⬇️

When it comes to treating mental and behavioral health, innovation is happening right here in Missouri. A few weeks ago, I visited community health centers and certified community behavioral health clinics across our state. Take a look to learn more ⬇️

As we prepare to mark Veterans Day, I spoke on the Senate floor this week to highlight the Senate’s efforts to honor the countless sacrifices of our brave veterans. We owe a tremendous debt of gratitude to these extraordinary men and women, and that’s why we have to continue working to live up to the promises we’ve made to them and their families.  http://bit.ly/2ApNgcK
More than 1,400 Missourians fought & died for our country in Vietnam. Their sacrifices will be forever remembered at the Vietnam Veterans Memorial sister wall in Perryville.

Our veterans represent the best of our nation. These extraordinary men and women and their families have made countless sacrifices to protect our freedom. It’s important that we honor them not just on Veterans Day, but every day. Please join me in thanking them.
Today, I joined Maria Bartiromo on Fox News's Sunday Morning Futures to discuss the Senate Republicans' tax reform plan ⬇️

According to the Tax Foundation, here’s how the Senate GOP's tax reform proposal will help middle-class families in Missouri ⬇️ ✅18,183 new full-time jobs ✅$2,421 gain in after-tax income  http://bit.ly/2yAHdRR

As co-chairs of the Congressional Coalition on Adoption, Senator Amy Klobuchar and I are committed to working with parents, advocates, and our colleagues to encourage adoption and raise awareness around children in need of families. The Senate passed our resolution marking November as National Adoption Month and November 18 as National Adoption Day.
Under the Senate GOP's tax bill, all income groups would see their taxes go ⬇️

The Tax Foundation estimates that middle-income Missouri families would see an increase of around $2,400 in their after-tax income under the Senate’s tax plan. Having an extra $200 per month would make a big difference for a lot of families. More from today’s Republican leadership press conference:
This is what the Tax Cuts & Jobs Act would mean for middle-class Missourians ⬇️

Today, I spoke on the Senate floor to highlight how the Senate Republican tax plan would benefit Missouri families and small businesses. According to the Tax Foundation, middle-income Missouri families would see an estimated increase of $2,400 in their after-tax income under the plan. http://bit.ly/2yICnlJ
The U.S. Capitol Christmas Tree will make a stop in Springfield next Tuesday at Bass Pro

I’m proud to announce that the bipartisan Military Family Stability Act, which I introduced earlier this year, is now headed to the president’s desk. This bill helps address one of the major challenges I hear from military families: an ill-timed move that takes a child out of school or prevents a husband or wife from pursuing an educational or career opportunity. The bill increases flexibility for military families by allowing them to either move early or remain at their current duty station for up to six months while their spouse begins a new assignment.

As co-chair of the Congressional Coalition on Adoption, I spoke on the Senate floor this week following Senate passage of legislation I introduced with Sen. Amy Klobuchar marking November as National Adoption Month and November 18 as National Adoption Day. I look forward to continuing our work to make it easier for families to adopt and to make sure adoptive families have the support they need. http://bit.ly/2myKTSA
Today, I joined Andrea Mitchell on NBC's Meet the Press to discuss tax reform and Senate efforts to address sexual harassment.
St. Louis Area Foodbank feeds 43,000 people each week. They do incredible work year round to help families in need, and I appreciated the opportunity to be a part of it today.

Yesterday, I met with Patriot Machine Inc. employees in St. Charles to discuss the Senate Republican tax plan. Our outdated tax code is taking money out of the pockets of hardworking Missourians and leaving families with too few opportunities to get ahead. The Senate GOP tax plan would lead to bigger paychecks, more jobs, and a more competitive economy.

I visited BCI (Boone Center Inc.) and had the opportunity to meet with employees. It was an inspiration to see the pride they take in their work.   BCI employs 400 adults with disabilities. Next year, they’ll open a vocational training facility for those with developmental and intellectual disabilities.
From my family to yours, Happy Thanksgiving!   Please join me in thanking our troops who are spending the holiday away from home to keep us safe.
The Senate Republican tax plan will provide much-needed tax relief to families and modernize our tax system.

Today, I had the opportunity to strike the 2018 WWI Centennial silver dollar at the United States Mint in Philadelphia. Four million Americans served in World War I, we must never forget the sacrifices they and their families made.

It was an honor to take part in the ceremonial strike of the 2018 World War I Centennial Silver Dollar at the United States Mint in Philadelphia yesterday. Missouri is home to the National World War I Museum and Memorial, which is why I’m especially proud to see that history remembered on the World War I American Veterans Centennial Commemorative Coin.

As President Trump made clear today, fixing our broken tax code is about two things: helping hardworking Missouri families keep more of what they earn and ensuring there are more opportunities and better-paying jobs for every American. I’ve heard from countless Missouri families, small business owners, and manufacturers about the challenges they face with our outdated tax code.  They need relief, and I appreciate President Trump’s push to make sure they get it.

A favorite holiday tradition - joining the American Red Cross to send holiday cards to our service members, veterans and their families who are at home and overseas.    If you’re interested in sending a card to thank and recognize our brave men and women in uniform and their families, please contact your local Red Cross for details.
LIVE: Small business owners and American workers share how tax reform will help their businesses grow and compete
Today, I held a press conference with Senate GOP, SBA Administrator Linda McMahon, and small business advocates to underscore the benefits of modernizing the tax code. http://bit.ly/2AKXxEz

Senate passage of the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act marks an important step toward providing real tax relief for Americans. This plan will mean more money in people's pockets today, and more jobs with higher wages in the future. We must continue working to get a bill to the president's desk this year. http://bit.ly/2khjHam
137 economists agree ➡️ The Tax Cuts & Jobs Act will lead to more jobs & higher wages

Yesterday, I spoke during the weekly Senate GOP leadership press conference to highlight the impact of the Senate’s Tax Cuts and Jobs Act. This bill will allow Missouri families to keep more of what they earn and pave the way for more jobs with better pay in the future
Today, I spoke on the Senate floor to highlight the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act and how it will allow Missouri families to keep more of what they earn and lead to more jobs with better pay.
On the 76th anniversary of the attack on Pearl Harbor, we honor and remember the men, women, and children lost on this “date which will live in infamy.” http://bit.ly/2AjkjDw

As co-chair of the Congressional Coalition on Adoption, I was proud to lead a bipartisan, bicameral letter urging the Prime Minister of Ethiopia to honor over 200 adoptions with American families that have been halted by the Ethiopian government.

Glad to see adoptions in Missouri are on the rise, but there are still far too many children in need of safe, permanent homes. That’s why I’ll continue working to make it easier for families to adopt.

Military families make countless sacrifices on behalf of our nation, and it’s our job to ensure they have the support they need to help manage the many challenges that come with military life.   That’s why I’m proud to announce that the president today signed into law my Military Family Stability Act. This bipartisan bill increases flexibility for military families by allowing them to either move early or remain at their current duty station for up to six months when a service member receives a new assignment.

The National Association of Manufacturers surveyed CEOs of 14,000 large & small manufacturers, here’s what they had to say about tax reform:   ✅Almost 54% said they would hire more workers  ✅More than half (57.9%) said they would expand their businesses   ✅Nearly half (48.8%) said they’d increase employee wages & benefits

Today, I spoke during the weekly Senate Republican leadership press conference to underscore the need to fill the more than 140 judicial vacancies we have in this country.   Despite needless delays from Senate Democrats, we’re on track to confirm a historic number of the president’s well-qualified nominees. That progress must continue.

The holiday season is an important time to reflect on everything our veterans and service members have done, and continue to do, to keep us safe. And, it’s an even more important time to honor that sacrifice with our actions. This year, I’ve introduced two bills that have been signed into law to encourage veterans’ hiring and provide more flexibility for military families. Read more about these bills here ⬇️

Today I spoke on the Senate floor to urge my Senate colleagues to confirm POTUS' judicial nominees. Filling these vacancies will help ensure Americans have access to the courts & preserve the judicial branch’s role as a check and balance on the executive and legislative branches.

I sat down with medical professionals, state officials & emergency responders in Springfield today for a roundtable discussion on how we can combat the opioid crisis. This epidemic is hurting communities in Missouri and across the nation, which why I've pushed for increased resources for treatment & prevention programs.

This morning, I visited the National Center for Advancing Translational Sciences (NCATS) to meet with National Institutes of Health (NIH) Director Francis Collins and NCATS Director Chris Austin. Through NCATS’ Clinical and Translational Science Award program, researchers at Washington University in St. Louis are currently working to detect & treat newborns for a rare neurological disorder called Niemann-Pick disease. Learn more: http://bit.ly/2BsxlMh

The Tax Cuts & Jobs Act will allow Americans to keep more of what they earn and eliminate Obamacare's individual mandate, which imposes a major tax penalty on middle-income families that can least afford it.
The Tax Cuts and Jobs Act will mean two things for hardworking families: More money in their pockets and paychecks today, and better jobs and stronger economic growth in the years to come.

From keeping our promises to veterans to providing tax cuts for hardworking families to rolling back excessive red tape, the Republican-led Senate and Trump administration have worked together this year to secure Missourians’ top priorities.
I may be biased but I think Missouri had the best ornaments on the National Christmas Tree. Jennifer Dodson really captured the Ozarks’ natural beauty: http://bit.ly/2hAShrR
From my family to yours, happy holidays.
To our brave men & women in uniform at home & overseas, thank you for your service. We owe you a deep debt of gratitude. From my family to yours, happy holidays.

Charlie, Abby and I spent the morning in Springfield volunteering at the Ozarks Food Harvest, helping box donated goods. The Ozarks Food Harvest serves 200+ hunger relief organizations across the Ozarks and feeds nearly 30,000 people each week.
